questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.
  • ➤ Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home

options.label: B
options.text: Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation

options.label: D
options.text: Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.correct_answer: D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with pneumonia, the CURB-65 score is a useful tool for determining the appropriate level of care. A score of 2 typically indicates the need for inpatient treatment in a non-ICU setting.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient

options.label: B
options.text: Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism

options.label: C
options.text: Screening of immigrants to a country

options.label: D
options.text: Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.correct_answer: C. Screening of immigrants to a country
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Screening of immigrants to a country

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Injury to which nerve results in absent gag reflex? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IX & X

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gag reflex involves the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for sensory input and the Vagus nerve (CN X) for motor response. Damage to either nerve can result in an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases

options.label: B
options.text: Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.correct_answer: D. Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat . This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.
  • ➤ Cefixime 400 mg stat

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coefficient of variation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 297
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 297

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urethritis is classified into two types:
  • ➤ Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  • ➤ Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common ) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common )
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (most common
  • ➤ Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ➤ Adenovirus
  • ➤ Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ➤ Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ➤ Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: Most common complication of untreated radial head dislocation is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cubitus varus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus varus deformity at the elbow.
  • ➤ The most common complication of an untreated radial head dislocation is the cubitus varus deformity at the elbow.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occipito-posterior

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Occipito-posterior:
  • • Occipito-posterior:
  • • History: Early rupture of membranes. Frequent filling of bladder. Premature bearing down. Abdominal Examination: Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus. Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions. Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly. Vaginal Examination: An elongated bag of membranes. The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint. The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.
  • • History: Early rupture of membranes. Frequent filling of bladder. Premature bearing down.
  • • History:
  • • Early rupture of membranes. Frequent filling of bladder. Premature bearing down.
  • • Early rupture of membranes.
  • • Frequent filling of bladder.
  • • Premature bearing down.
  • • Abdominal Examination: Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus. Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions. Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • • Abdominal Examination:
  • • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus. Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions. Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
  • • Inspection:
  • • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
  • • Grips:
  • • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • • Auscultation:
  • • Vaginal Examination: An elongated bag of membranes. The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint. The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.
  • • Vaginal Examination:
  • • An elongated bag of membranes. The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint. The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.
  • • An elongated bag of membranes.
  • • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
  • • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.
  • • Option A. Brow:
  • • Option B. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.
  • • Option B. Knee:
  • • Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.
  • • Option D. Right dorso-anterior:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3 rd edition

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.
  • ➤ Hyperopia

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 6th arch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve : The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with spotting PV following insertion of an IUD. What is the best management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iron supplementation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron supplementation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.
  • ➤ Iron supplementation

questions.text: Paris green powder is used for killing of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anopheles larva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antilarval measures: Paris green – 2% dust applied in dose of 1 kg per hectare; ‘stomach poison’ to larvae but harmless to humans, animals or fish
  • ➤ Antiadult measures: DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quinsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: What is the compression to ventilation ratio in an adult cardiac arrest patient in the presence of more than one rescuer?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For adult CPR, regardless of the number of rescuers, the compression to ventilation ratio should always be 30:2 to ensure effective circulation and oxygenation during cardiac arrest.
  • ➤ Additionally, For children with one rescuer, the ratio is 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2) ; with two rescuers, the ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2) . For neonates , the ratio is 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1) .
  • ➤ For children
  • ➤ 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2)
  • ➤ 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2)
  • ➤ For neonates
  • ➤ 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the OPD with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. On workup, it reveals normocytic normochromic anemia with hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis was done that shows M Spike in gamma region. Which of the following should be used to confirm the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: B. Bence Jones proteins in urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bence Jones proteins in urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is a key diagnostic test for confirming multiple myeloma, especially when the clinical presentation includes back pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and an M spike on serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amyloid beta plaque is a key pathological marker of Alzheimer’s disease, contributing significantly to the neurodegenerative changes seen in this condition.

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications. They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death. Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons. It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.
  • • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers:
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa:
  • • Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.
  • • Option D. Labetalol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Following image shows Casal’s Necklace & hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed limbs:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickettsial diseases:
  • ➤ Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Xenopsylla cheopis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: A woman purchased a food item from a shopkeeper who was subsequently arrested for food adulteration. Meanwhile, the woman develops visual disturbances and cardiac failure. The underlying toxin is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sanguinarine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Food Adulteration diseases:
  • ➤ Food Adulteration diseases:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: D. Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.
  • ➤ Remember -
  • ➤ Remember -
  • ➤ Drugs used: Methylphenidate: alpha agonist Dx methylphenidate Dextro amphetamine Atomoxetine: antidepressant Tricyclic antidepressants like Imipramine Clonidine, guanfacine
  • ➤ Drugs used:
  • ➤ Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • ➤ Dx methylphenidate
  • ➤ Dextro amphetamine
  • ➤ Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • ➤ Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • ➤ Imipramine
  • ➤ Clonidine, guanfacine

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads). Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays. Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.
  • • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.
  • • Option B. Terminate pregnancy:
  • • Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.
  • • Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test:
  • • Option D. Chromosome screening : Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.
  • • Option D.
  • • Chromosome
  • • screening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chancroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in Opioid Substitution Therapy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opioid Substitution Therapy involves replacing a harmful opioid with a safer opioid like oral buprenorphine or methadone during the maintenance phase of treatment.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B (Rice)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).
  • ➤ Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).
  • ➤ Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.
  • ➤ Other sources

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity. MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity: A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity: Deep tendon reflexes Respiratory Rate Urine Output Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)
  • • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity: Deep tendon reflexes Respiratory Rate Urine Output
  • • Deep tendon reflexes Respiratory Rate Urine Output
  • • Deep tendon reflexes
  • • Respiratory Rate
  • • Urine Output
  • • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
  • • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
  • • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis : This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.
  • • Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • • Option C. Postpartum eclampsia : This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures
  • • Option C. Postpartum eclampsia
  • • Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy : There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely
  • • Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.correct_answer: B. Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: A forensic doctor is facing criminal charges for malpractice in a district criminal court and is also summoned to provide expert testimony in a district civil court for which he will be provided compensation. What is the correct statement in this scenario? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: C
options.text: Attend the summon which was received earlier

options.label: D
options.text: Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Attend Criminal Court

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When receiving summons from multiple courts, the priority is determined by the following factors:
  • • Court Rank : Higher courts take precedence over lower courts. Case Type : Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases. The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended. Timeliness : If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.
  • • Court Rank : Higher courts take precedence over lower courts.
  • • Court Rank
  • • Case Type : Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases. The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended.
  • • Case Type
  • • Timeliness : If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.
  • • Timeliness
  • • In this case:
  • • Both courts are of same rank (district court) One case is criminal and other is civil Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered
  • • Both courts are of same rank (district court)
  • • One case is criminal and other is civil
  • • Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Attend Civil Court: Incorrect. Even though compensation is offered, civil court attendance does not take precedence over criminal court when summons are received simultaneously.
  • • Option B. Attend Civil Court:
  • • Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier: Incorrect. While timing of summons receipt is a criterion, it only applies when both courts are of same rank and type. Criminal cases take precedence regardless of when summons was received.
  • • Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier:
  • • Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon: Incorrect. Ignoring court summons and waiting for second summons is not appropriate. One must attend according to the priority.
  • • Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Order of Court Ranking (Highest to Lowest):
  • ➤ Order of Court Ranking (Highest to Lowest):
  • ➤ Supreme Court & High Court Sessions Court / District Court / Additional Sessions Judge / Additional District Judge Assistant Sessions Judge Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM) / Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM) 1st Class Judicial Magistrate (JM) / Metropolitan Magistrate (MM) 2nd Class Judicial Magistrate (JM)
  • ➤ Supreme Court & High Court
  • ➤ Sessions Court / District Court / Additional Sessions Judge / Additional District Judge
  • ➤ Assistant Sessions Judge
  • ➤ Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM) / Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM)
  • ➤ 1st Class Judicial Magistrate (JM) / Metropolitan Magistrate (MM)
  • ➤ 2nd Class Judicial Magistrate (JM)

questions.text: A patient present with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic triad of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency): gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae/easy bruising. Understand that these symptoms occur due to impaired collagen synthesis and compromised blood vessel integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Mechanism of botulinum toxin: (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting acetylcholine release from presynaptic terminals. It specifically acts by:
  • • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures
  • • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • • Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • • SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • • neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • • This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft
  • • Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release
  • • Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect because botulinum toxin doesn't affect reuptake mechanisms. It acts specifically on the release mechanism.
  • • Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action for myasthenia gravis where antibodies target post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. Botulinum toxin acts presynaptically.
  • • Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action of drugs like neostigmine and pyridostigmine used in treating myasthenia gravis. They prevent the breakdown of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
  • • Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin functions by inhibiting acetylcholine release through its action on SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin ) at the presynaptic terminal.
  • ➤ SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty switching from one movement to another, along with uncontrollable hand movements. Identify the abnormality: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dysdiadochokinesia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dysdiadochokinesia refers to the inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly and refers to cerebellar dysfunction. From the clinical presentation described - difficulty switching movements and uncontrollable hand movements - this is a classic case of dysdiadochokinesia.
  • • difficulty switching movements and uncontrollable hand movements
  • • Di : two Docho: alternate Kinesis: movement
  • • Di : two
  • • Di
  • • Docho: alternate
  • • Docho:
  • • Kinesis: movement
  • • Kinesis:
  • • This is one of the key signs of cerebellar disease, specifically affecting the coordination of voluntary movements.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Intentional tremor: This occurs when a patient is performing a purposeful action and gets worse as they approach the target.
  • • Option B. Intentional tremor:
  • • Option C. Metamorphosis: This is seen in lesions of the amygdala or temporal lobe and refers to an uncontrollable urge to respond to every stimulus. It's not related to movement disorders.
  • • Option C. Metamorphosis:
  • • Option D. Resting tremor: This is primarily seen in Parkinson's disease and occurs when the affected body part is at rest.
  • • Option D. Resting tremor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysdiadochokinesia is a cerebellar sign characterized by inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly.

questions.text: A long-standing smoker has shortness of breath, and spirometry shows FEV₁ 60% with FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.6. Which of the following is the likely cause of the findings in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) COPD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.7 indicates obstructive lung disease. COPD is the most common obstructive lung disease in smokers, while conditions like silicosis and interstitial lung disease present with restrictive patterns (normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio).

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for eliciting the corneal reflex during the corneal wisp test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trigeminal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex) is a protective mechanism that causes involuntary blinking when the cornea is touched. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components. During a corneal wisp test, a cotton wisp or similar object is brought in from the side (to avoid eliciting a visual reflex) and gently touches the cornea.
  • • The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) serves as the afferent (sensory) pathway for this reflex. Specifically, the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries the sensory information from the cornea when it is stimulated. The sensory information is then processed, and an efferent (motor) response is generated via the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, resulting in the blink.
  • • The corneal sensitivity can be tested more precisely using an instrument called an aesthesiometer, which measures the minimal stimulus required to elicit the blink reflex. Corneal sensation is characteristically decreased in viral corneal ulcers, making this test diagnostically valuable.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oculomotor nerve : Incorrect. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is responsible for most eye movements by controlling four of the six extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle (responsible for eyelid elevation) and carries parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation. It has no role in corneal sensation or the blink reflex pathway.
  • • Option A. Oculomotor nerve
  • • Option C. Abducens nerve : Incorrect. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye (moving the eye outward, away from the nose). It has no sensory function and does not participate in the corneal reflex pathway.
  • • Option C. Abducens nerve
  • • Option D. Facial nerve : Incorrect, but partially involved in the reflex arc. While the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is involved in the corneal reflex, it serves as the efferent (motor) pathway, not the afferent pathway. The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which causes the eyelid to close during blinking. The question specifically asks about the nerve responsible for "eliciting" the reflex, which refers to the sensory component (trigeminal nerve), not the motor response.
  • • Option D. Facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corneal reflex is mediated by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) as the afferent (sensory) pathway and the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) as the efferent (motor) pathway.
